displayed_text: Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it? Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body.

Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent.

Patient: Wow, wow. Doctor: So, then the next day when, you know, it was Monday afternoon my patient called and he goes okay, we’re never gonna do that again. I’m like, because he got his dose like Friday Patient: Right. Doctor: and then he traveled Sunday and I was like okay, that will teach you not to do that. So, now, I reported that back so now every single time, and they didn’t give him the card because they’re like it’s so low you won’t Patient: You won’t know yeah. Doctor: set off anything, you’ll be fine. After that incident, everybody gets a card. That’s a longwinded way of saying, everybody gets a card. Patient: Everybody gets card, okay. Now is that here? Doctor: Yeah. So, there is a Dr. M____. We’re gonna write this down for you guys Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: and then we’ll make the referral but just so you know we’ll start the prior authorization process so by the time you see him we’ve got everything under way and then he’ll just take over. Patient: Okay and then I see you after or during? Doctor: Right, so like I’m kind of just hovering because we’re trying not to add more work.

Patient: it I mean an x-ray to look at it that may be even a replacement here or something’s been compromised here or the cancer side? Doctor: Well yeah or if it’s just arthritis then we often just… Patient: I see. Doctor: … we can all just be happy or Patient: Okay. Doctor: At some point you’ll probably get a knee-hip replacement. Patient: Yeah. Well I know that’s true. Doctor: But that’s a whole ‘nother story. But that way if you do call me one day out of the blue, I’m gonna be like yeah we just checked your hip thing remember and it was a couple months ago and you were fine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Blood work… Doctor: Might as well get it done. Patient: Blood work everything – can I do that with the Zometa too or when we do the Zometa Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Everybody’s like taking pictures. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. She took some good pictures with our camera. I ain’t lying. She took some good pictures. Doctor: And so do you have to drive like far from where you’re staying to get to the park? Is that why you have to get up so early? Family Member: Well they, because the animals is up early. Patient: No. Doctor: No. But I mean you’re not like driving three hours to get there? Patient: No. Family Member: No. Patient: No. Uh-uh. No. We, we had to drive that far to get there, but- Doctor: Did you stay like in a hotel or where did you stay at? Family Member: It was in a hotel. Then they get the bus to pick up at the hotel, then it takes you to the, uh, park, and then you get in this- Patient: You get in those little trucks.

Patient: I might toot, but then after that no problems. Doctor: Very good. So it sounds like everything else is fine. Any new medical problems with your heart, lungs, bowels are functioning fine? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay fine. Patient: No. Doctor: So we just got to resolve this social issue. Patient: Yes. Doctor: That’s the biggest thing. Patient: Is it time for me to get up you know. Doctor: Yes, I hear ya. Patient: You know from the biopsy, not by biopsy from my colonoscopy I’ve been asking you about when we wait some more. Doctor: Yeah right yes.

Family Member: The scan will detect-? Doctor: If you have the PSMA. If you have that antigen or not in your cells. Then that will help us decide whether we put you on the study or not. Patient: And you can’t get it here in the states? Doctor: Not yet. Family Member: The scan. Doctor: The scan you can get. Patient: Right. Doctor: The actual treatment, also, like I said, on the study, there’s a two out of three chance that you will get the treatment. Okay? Uh, A___? I’ll tell S___ to come in. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: But, uh, you know, I think it is a chance, and none of us have any control over what you get. But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyway. Patient: Yeah. Uh, the last time that that you saw a spot or spots on my bone, you used radiation to go with it. Doctor: Right. Patient: So what, what’s the difference this time? Doctor: Well, I think we saw, you know, a few, you know, small number of spots. We thought like we could radiate them. Maybe those are the only spots. Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, all the new studies are like hey, radium and phone a friend, you know, radium and Xtandi, radium and chemo, radium and whatever. So, they’re all in studies but not standard of care yet. I’m gonna pause right there and see how you guys are doing. This is not a test. There’s no test. No test. Family Member: Okay, he was asking when we were waiting for you. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If the treatment you’re going to give him is going to make him feel better Patient: Yes. Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no?

Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Because the other thing too is uh I coach my daughters softball team so of course get that grade down, a bucket of ball (FAM Laughs) Doctor: So even a year or two from now it’s not gonna be – you don’t have as much resistance to outflow as you used to have. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Uh those pills they didn’t do anything. Doctor: Okay well don’t stop taking ‘em because… Patient: Well I took ‘em. Doctor: Oh you so you finished taking them and you ran out of them is what you mean? Patient: Yeah, yeah I took ‘em. Doctor: You should have some refills. Did you look at the bottle? Patient: Well you know I ordered some more yeah. Doctor: Oh you got a refill. Patient: I haven’t been doing better. Doctor: Okay but stay with them because what it does it’s not gonna be immediate, it allows the blood flow to go into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And take it uh like twice a week.

Family Member: Okay. Well that’s fine. Doctor: ‘Cuz in this clinic, (laughs) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It’s automatic. Appointment. PSA. Appointment. So, that’s what they did, too. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Of course. It’s still the same? The PSA. Doctor: So. It’s, it’s not back yet. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Hopefully, it hasn’t changed in two weeks. Doctor: Your sugars are high, though. Are you on – remind me, Are you diabetic? I can’t remember. Patient: Yeah. I have type two diabetes. Doctor: So, your sugar was high today. Three hundred. You probably didn’t fast.

Patient: In part of the work that I do, she was --- I do race disability Doctor: Yeah, you told me that, yeah. Patient: So, they were interested in what, how I answered questions. Anyway. Doctor: Alright. You did a good job. You get an A. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: I don’t even know if this things still working. Family Member: We’re all movie, movie stars now. Doctor: Yeah, it probably didn’t work. Gotta do it all over. Take two! Family Member: My experience is that she’ll get it if it is --- Patient: Okay, doc, good to see you again. Doctor: Good seeing you, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Safe travels.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then something like the Zofran or Ondansetron that you have at home is what we use in the middle of the week if you had nausea after the chemo. Family Member: Mm. Tiredness was my biggest obstacle. Doctor: Tired is definitely. Family Member: Fatigue was unbelievable. So have you decided? Patient: Too early to decide. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: Yeah, so we need more information about the chest scan. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I want to give you some stuff that you can sort of read to educate yourself a bit more on options. And again you can lay it off to Dr. G as to his thoughts as to what the next steps would be in terms of scans or such. So other questions while I do a little bit more of this paperwork stuff? (keyboarding) Family Member: No, I don’t think so. Patient: I can’t think of anything. Did you go to M___?

Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play. Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation.
